SELECT COMMITTEE ON ASSEMBLY STAFF


    The Chief Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, the motion that stands in my name seeks the appointment of a Select Committee with you as Chairman to consider the question of staffing, both as regards personnel and conditions of service, for this Assembly. I cannot do better, Sir, than use your own words, when discussing this matter with me, when you said, "It is essential and desirable that the fact that the Assembly staff is independent of the Government should be widely known and should be absolutely obvious." I could not agree more, Sir. Although we, on this Bench, have the privilege and the honour today of being the Government, we are also Members of this Assembly, and we are acutely conscious of the necessity of this Assembly being absolutely independent of the Government of the day, being able to control its own staff and provide the necessities that it deems requisite for its existence and its proceedings.

    At present, Sir, there is no friction at all. No one can vouch for the future. At present all the staff are appointed by Government and are subject to General Orders. The motion that stands in my name seeks the appointment of a Committee which will itself recommend the appointment of staff as regards personnel, and which it is hoped will produce a scheme, to be approved by this House, of salaries, remuneration and conditions of service, so that this House will have employees, who are paid through Government agency with its approval, absolutely independent of Government control.

SINGAPORE ESSENTIAL (AMENDMENT) REGULATIONS, 1955


    The Attorney-General (Mr E. J. Davies): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move the motion standing in my name on the Order Paper, namely,

    That this Assembly, pursuant to subsection (2) of section 3 of the Transfer of Powers and interpretation Ordinance, 1949 (No. 9 of 1949), resolves that the Singapore Essential (Amendment) Regulations, 1955, published as Notification No. S 216 in the Gazette Supplement No. 65 of 13th August, 1955, as contained in Sessional Paper No. S.L. 26 of 1955, be approved.

    Sir, the Essential Regulations originally passed in 1945 have been kept alive for the purpose of enabling the determination of a very substantial claim for compensation by the major oil companies arising out of the requisition

Column: 641

of stocks of oil by the British reoccupying authorities. The claim is being heard by the Compensation Board set up under those Regulations, and the President of the Board, who is a Judge of the Supreme Court, has made representations to Government that Regulation 54, which refers to appeals from decisions of the Board, should be clarified so as to ensure that there is no doubt whatever as to the right of appeal by either party to the dispute from the decision of the Board.

    Very complicated issues of law, both international and municipal, are involved, as well as a considerable sum of money, running into millions of dollars, and the dispute will probably be taken all the way to the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council.

    The amendments which the Regulations make are based on those provisions relating to appeals from the Income Tax Board of Review. They have had the approval of the President of the Compensation Board and the agreement of counsel on both sides. In these circumstances, Sir, I would ask that this Assembly approves of the Regulations.

    The Financial Secretary (Mr T. M. Hart): I second it.

    Question put, and agreed to.

APPOINTMENT OF MORE ASSISTANT MINISTERS


    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Mr Speaker, Sir, over a month ago the Press published an item on a move by the Chief Minister to appoint more Assistant Ministers. This immediately drew a great deal of adverse criticism from the

Column: 643

public. I have met hundreds of people since then, and every time I put the question to them they return the answer 'No'. I put it to the businessmen, and they are also of that opinion. I have talked it over with office workers, clerks and all, and they also come forward with the same answer. I have even heard from people in the streets - hawkers and labourers - people who congregate in their usual haunts, say coffee shops, and the conclusion they have ever come to is always 'No'. That is the strong feeling of the people about the appointment of Assistant Ministers.

    From the other section, we have the Press. They are also fully aware of the opinion of the people, and I think everybody in this House knows it. They criticise this move of the Chief Minister, and they support the opinion of the people. In this one case, we can say that opinion in Singapore is unanimous. They are all opposed to this question of the appointment of more Assistant Ministers.

    From their accounts and from the views they have aired, the people of Singapore have indicated that this question is one of public interest and, such being the case, should deserve the attention of the Assembly. However, as a Member of this House, I have received no official indication of this matter until after the release of the correspondence between His Excellency the Governor and the Chief Minister. I voice this because in a matter which the people of Singapore believe to be of great interest, their representatives in this Assembly should, at the very least, be given first-hand information.

    Now we come on to another aspect of the question. If public opinion had been taken into consideration - and rightly so - then this question of Assistant Ministers would not have plunged us into a constitutional crisis.

    An hon. Member: What a pity that would have been!

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: The Chief Minister during the debate on 18th August informed us that the appointment of Assistant Ministers is a very

Column: 644

minor issue, that matters concerning the constitution are of the first importance. I agree with that and I think it should remain so.

    Now the constitutional crisis is over. We have got the answer from His Excellency the Governor, and we have had the answer to the first three parts of the Resolution concerning the interpretation of the constitution given us. If this matter of appointment of Assistant Ministers were to be pushed, it would seem then that the Government side was using that as a lever to get what it wanted. You will note in my motion that we do not say that you must not, you cannot, appoint Assistant Ministers. We say that at the present time it is undesirable, because it will give the people of Singapore a thoroughly wrong impression, and it will put a thing that is of first importance in not too good a light.

    We would also like to draw the attention of hon. Members of this House to the very small number of elected representatives. We have only 25 elected Members, and this small number is divided between those sitting on the Government side and those on the Opposition side. That leaves us a Coalition Government with a total of 13 elected Members, two nominated and three official Members. We have on the Government side nine Ministers, one Assistant Minister, and one Deputy Speaker. That leaves us with only seven Government Back-benchers. If another four Members were to be appointed as Assistant Ministers, then we would have a sorry state of affairs where the Government has even less followers than leaders.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Is that not the case?

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: Should the threat of the appointment of an Assistant Minister to every Ministry be carried out, then we would have the ludicrous situation of the Government having to persuade at least one Member of the Opposition to join them and be made an Assistant Minister. My sincere hope is that such a situation should never happen and that Singapore should not be made an object of ridicule to the world at large. It is ridiculous.

Column: 645



    Again let us remember that of the nine Ministers we have on the Government Benches, five of them are always in the forefront of public opinion. They are in the forefront of public opinion by virtue of the fact that they were elected by the people. In the eyes of our neighbours, they are the people who are in charge of the affairs of Singapore for the very first time. We do agree that their responsibilities are great, perhaps greater than the official Members, but let it be said that they are responsible people, that they are not afraid of hard work, that they are not afraid of great, or even greater work and responsibilities. Let it be said that they can discharge their responsibilities ably and efficiently. Any attempt to add Assistant Ministers to these Ministries without extremely good reasons will create an impression that may not be favourable to us, the people who have a say in the affairs of Singapore.

    Now since the subject of the appointment of Assistant Ministers was broached - and it was a short while back - we remember that the Chief Minister in an address first said that it was one of necessity. Later on we had another Press release saying that it was one of training. Now we agree that our local people must be trained, but we must also remember that Assistant Ministers are not going to be our permanent civil servants. They may not remain in the service for a long time. After receiving their training, they may not come back again. There are too many uncertainties. But let us be generous about it - they may not want to contest any more elections; they may want to withdraw voluntarily. Or the people may get tired of all this play and no work, and they may not be returned again. There are too many uncertainties. Public money must be spent wisely. All the same, the cost of training will be very high. It will cost the taxpayer $1,500 per month for every Assistant Minister - $18,000 per annum. Four Assistant Ministers, if appointed, will cost us $72,000 per annum. This figure will exceed $160,000 per annum if we have all the nine Assistant Ministers appointed.

Column: 646



    I am thinking about this because the Chief Minister, during the elections, did promise the electorate that he would keep the cost of government down. That was not very long ago. How is he going to reconcile this with his electorate? This is a matter between him and his constituency. I would rather leave it at that!

    Suppose we even agree to the appointment of more Assistant Ministers - and we say that it is a matter of training - it must be admitted that most of us here are new to this business of government. We are all learners. If you put an Assistant Minister to be guided by another one as fresh as the one appointed, it would appear to me like putting a person, who is learning how to drive a car, under the care and direction of another learner.

    Now all these things do indicate to us that it is not desirable at this very moment to appoint Assistant Ministers. Perhaps after we have gained a little bit more experience and we have an enlarged House, this question may be brought up again. So, Sir, on these grounds, I move,

    That this House is of opinion that the appointment of more Assistant Ministers at the present time is undesirable.

    Mr John Ede (Tanglin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to second the motion. The issue before us is a perfectly simple one even if recent events have tended to cloud it over. It is whether or not the appointment of more Assistant or Junior Ministers, or Parliamentary Secretaries, will be conducive to better and more efficient government within the context of the present constitution with its Assembly of 32 Members. The constitutional question does not enter into this motion. It is purely a question of whether the present administration will be improved or not by such appointments.

    As I suggested in this House previously, can it really be desirable that in a Government of 18 Members, there should be 14 posts - four additional Assistant Ministers being the original issue - and if you like to include the unpaid posts of Government Whip and Deputy Speaker, 16 or half this House;

Column: 647

and would this be desirable even if the Chief Minister could call on all the talent in Singapore to pick from? We are not convinced on this point, nor are we convinced - and this is the real issue - that it will result in really efficient government.

    What are the proper functions of Ministers? Surely these do not and need not go beyond the dictation of policy, the control of policy and the issuing of directives to see that their policy is carried out by the departments through the Permanent Secretaries? I will grant that it may take three months, or even six months, for a new Minister to find this out and find his feet, but after that, he should be on top of his job. The fact of the matter is that there are now two men at the top - the Minister and the Permanent Secretary - to drive the machinery of the department, instead of one as before. Assistant Ministers would make it three instead of one, and anyone who knows anything about administration surely knows that too many men at the top mean bottlenecks and delay, or contradictions and confusion.

    But what are the Assistant Ministers functions to be? They cannot take full charge of a department, as they must always refer to the Minister, who is responsible to the Council of Ministers for the policy laid down by him. If they are to be understudies, then they are to gain experience from those who themselves are still learning.

    We have, however, a clue, and a very disturbing clue, in a statement the Chief Minister made to the Press sometime ago stating his reasons for wanting Assistant Ministers. His third reason apparently was to strengthen his hold over the non-domiciled civil service to ensure that his new policies are carried out. Now the Press may have misquoted him, and I am sure my hon. Friend will correct me if I am wrong, but I understand that to mean, firstly, that expatriate officers are not loyally carrying out the policies of the Government, and secondly, the Assistant Ministers are intended to be bearers from the Chief Minister of directives on policy in departments in which the Chief Minister has no direct control. The first is a very

Column: 648

serious allegation to make. Even if it were true, have the officers, in fact, been given any policy to carry out? We on this side of the House have seen no signs that the Government has a policy in very many matters, in matters of great importance -

    The Chief Minister: Such as?

    Mr John Ede: The second, -

    The Chief Minister: Such as?

    Mr Speaker: Order, please.

    Mr John Ede: - if true, is hardly flattering to the Chief Minister's own fellow-Ministers. If interference is at the root of the matter, then it is better that the Ministers should be left free to get on with their jobs rather than have expensive recourse to Assistant Ministers with their salaries, plus the extra expense of their offices, office staff, Permanent Secretaries, and the rest of it.

    So far I have only referred to the Ministries which were mentioned in the official correspondence between the Governor and the Chief Minister, that is to say, those four Ministries to which it was originally intended to attach Assistant Ministers. But it may be that finding that this was not a popular move in more quarters than one that the Government has been looking for a way out, and it has been re-reading the Rendel Report with its reference to the fact that an Assistant Minister might be appointed to understudy the Financial Secretary, with its logical extension to the other ex-officio portfolios. Now if the Rendel Report is to be our Bible - and it seems to be very much less of a Bible than it was a few weeks ago when this motion was first tabled - there might be something in this argument, on two conditions: firstly, that there are men of the highest qualifications on the Government side today available to understudy one or more of these onerous portfolios; secondly, that they would, in fact, he trained with a view to their taking over these portfolios in the near future. I do not think that these conditions can be fulfilled at the present time.

    The issue before us, therefore, is this: Will the Assistant Ministers' appointments produce a more efficient administration? If hon. Members think that

Column: 649

they will not - I have given reasons to show that they are ill-conceived - then they must vote in favour of this motion. If the Chief Minister is still seriously considering the appointments of Assistant Ministers or Parliamentary Secretaries, whichever you like to call them, I would ask him to ponder once more in all seriousness: Will the Government, which is almost all Front Bench with no Back-benchers, be a satisfactory democratic government? Will it not suffer from a lack of self-criticism? Will it not be rather too subservient to the policies of the Chief Minister, resulting in autocratic and not democratic methods, a tendency which we of the Progressive Party have criticised in the past with real concern?

    The Chief Minister: When you were in power?

    Mr John Ede: If the ways of democracy are to be established on this island, they must not only flourish, but be seen to flourish. The next nine months, which must be months of calm and good sense if full confidence is to be restored, are the testing time. I speak with the greatest sincerity when I say that we, in this part of the House, would be the more inspired to make the fullest contribution to that calm and good sense in the coming months if the Chief Minister will be, as we think it, far-sighted enough to eschew making appointments which, I am convinced, in the unbalance of the Government Benches they would cause, may do untold harm to the democratic institutions which it should be our first concern at this stage to foster.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy (Telok Ayer): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to support the motion before the House.

    Singapore is a small island of only about 230 square miles -

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: All man-made.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy: - not 90 square miles as the Chief Minister yesterday by mistake - [Interruption.]

    Mr Speaker: Order, please.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy: - said. It has only a population of 1,200,000, one-thirtieth part of Calcutta, our nearest

Column: 650

city. Up to the time of the election, the cost of running the government was 53 to 55 per cent, which is indeed very, very high.

    Now, Sir, after the election, you have Ministers with their salaries, their staff with their salaries, with their entertainment plus the expenses of cameramen to give them publicity! Sir, this all adds to the cost from the revenue. How is it to be met? I have said on many occasions that we have got no natural resources. To meet the cost, we will have to find a way to increase the revenue, which will be a burden not only to the rich, but also to the poor.

    Sir, before this Government came into power, or before the election, we had hon. Members of the Legislative Council who did the work of legislation and also ran the Government departments. Those gentlemen are now the Permanent Secretaries, and they are very efficient men. They are not to do any legislative work now, but their whole time is to be devoted to carrying out the policies laid down by the Ministers. When you have got such efficient men at the helm to carry out the policies of the Ministers, where is the necessity of having further Assistant Ministers?

    Sir, in the Labour Front we have ten elected Members. Out of them, four are Ministers and one is an Assistant Minister. I do not count the Hon. the Minister for Communications and Works (Mr Francis Thomas) because he is a nominated Member. He is sitting there at the pleasure of the Government. If the Government falls, he also falls too; so I do not count him at all. So, five elected Labour Front Members have got, should I say, jobs, or should I say, Ministerial posts, then only five are left. Out of them, two are recommended to be Assistant Ministers, according to the correspondence between the Chief Minister and His Excellency which has been circulated to us - one to be drawn from the Opposition and one from the Alliance. In other words, out of ten, seven Labour Front elected Members will have Ministerial posts if they are nominated. This is very ridiculous - out of ten, seven getting jobs, three as Back-benchers. Why is this being done?

Column: 651



    Sir, we have here the Progressive Party, very long and well established. Here you have got another very big Party called the P.A.P. - a regular Party. Then you have got the U.M.N.O. Alliance. They are all regular Parties, having a paying membership, having regular monthly or yearly meetings, and having their own offices. In other words, these Parties are run on proper party lines.

    Now take the Labour Front Party. What is it? Is it a Party? If I may be allowed to quote, a Press digest dated 16th July, 1955, of a vernacular newspaper - it is the Tamil Murasu, a Tamil paper, Sir. I quote:

    "The Chief Minister of Singapore has explained and given his reasons for attempting to appoint four Assistant Ministers, but none of these reasons seems to be satisfactory to anyone. The argument that the administration of Singapore could be carried on effectively only with six Ministers and five Assistant Ministers is not an appropriate one.

    Differences of opinion existed within the Labour Front, even the Ministers chosen for the Council of Ministers. The Chief Minister may deny this, and say that all is well with the Labour Front, but those who are aware of the condition of the Labour Front would not accept this.

    Even the work of the Labour Front was a complicated affair. The leaders of the Party have no opportunity to do the things which would establish the Party in a proper manner. Even they could not answer the question whether or not the Party has developed and taken its full shape."

    Now, Sir, this is the position: here is the Labour Front Party in coalition with the Alliance running the government, and in order to keep the Party members together - if this is an insinuation, Sir, I am willing to withdraw it.

    Mr Speaker: Is the hon. Member imputing improper motives?

    The Chief Minister: I will tell a few home truths about him!

    Mr R. Jumabhoy: I will be very happy -
